transcript.title: Doorstop at Old Parliament House, Canberra - Fifth National Indigenous Heritage Art Award 2000
transcript.content:
Subjects: Fifth National Indigenous Heritage Art Award 2000

E&OEâ¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦

PRIME MINISTER:

I think theyâre very good. I think what they do is enable the community to recognise indigenous artists and the quality is superb and gives everybody a sense of identification with their own culture. So I think itâs great. And you can see from the enthusiasm of people who won the awards just how important it is to them. And I think itâs important to the rest of us to have an opportunity to honour the special nature of indigenous artists. And itâs part of the reconciliation process to respect each othersâ abilities and special characteristics. I think theyâre great evenings and Iâm delighted to play a small part. I think itâs great to have companies like Rothschilds making a financial contribution and I want to compliment Peter King and the Heritage Commission for their leadership in sponsoring the awards.

JOURNALIST:

Do you have full confidence in Peter Cosgrove over his handling of these recent allegations?

PRIME MINISTER:

Yes, absolutely, totally, 100%.

[Ends]
